fullProgramDescription: The Bachelor of Science degree in Electrical Engineering is offered by the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering. The program provides a comprehensive foundation in electrical engineering, including circuit analysis, electronics, digital systems, computer architecture, signals and systems, and electromagnetic fields. Students gain hands-on experience through laboratory courses and electives, preparing them for a wide range of careers or graduate study.
shortProgramDescription: The Electrical Engineering B.S. program at UC San Diego provides a rigorous foundation in core areas of electrical engineering, preparing students for diverse careers or further study.
classHighlights: Core electrical engineering courses include Circuit Analysis (ECE 101), Electronics (ECE 102), Digital Systems (ECE 25), and Electromagnetic Fields (ECE 107/107L).
Students complete a sequence of mathematics courses, including Calculus (MATH 20A-B-C-D) and Differential Equations (MATH 20D, MATH 21D).
Foundational physics courses cover Mechanics (PHYS 2A or 4A) and Electricity & Magnetism (PHYS 2B or 4B).
Advanced ECE courses cover topics such as Signals and Systems (ECE 101), Communication Systems (ECE 154A), Control Systems (ECE 171A), and VLSI Design (ECE 111).
Laboratory courses, including ECE 35, ECE 100, and ECE 111L, provide hands-on experience with electrical engineering principles and design.
Electives allow students to explore specialized areas, including computer architecture, digital signal processing, and power systems.
learningOutcomes: Apply mathematical and scientific principles to analyze and design electrical engineering systems.
Demonstrate understanding of circuit analysis, electronics, and digital systems.
Use laboratory equipment and software tools to measure, analyze, and design electrical systems.
Communicate technical information effectively in written and oral forms.
Work effectively in teams to solve engineering problems.
Understand the ethical and societal implications of electrical engineering.
additionalInformation: Students must complete lower-division requirements before advancing to upper-division courses. The program has specific GPA and course requirements. Transfer credits and AP/IB credits may apply with department approval.
